1.words: Okay. So first just to kind of go over again, purpose of the conversation, creating new spaces across the city to facilitate more constructive listening just across neighborhoods and communities and really building an ecosystem of listening where every community member's stories contributes to our shared understanding and building a stronger and more inclusive Boston. So really inviting you to engage in this conversation. Share from your personal stories and your own lives and experiences rather than, we sometimes do a lot of opinions or things of other people, but it's always great to stick to what you've experienced and what you know. And so this approach really aims to build connections, to facilitate conversations that deepen mutual understanding. Second, I want to address what's going to happen to the recording. So after our meeting, this is going to be part of the collection of the conversation. So this conversation, along with other conversations that are taking place throughout the city, will be shared with members of the Real Talk at Boston team, which consists of 14 community-based organizations in the city of Boston and it'll also be shared with the MIT Center for Contractive Communication. Thirdly, all conversations that will be a part of this effort will become part of the conversation platform. It's developed by their nonprofit organization called Cortico. So it's the MIT Center's development arm, and they have a FORA system that creates a transcript for each recording. And so we're going to upload the audio, it'll develop a transcript, and then we pull patterns and highlights from each conversation to be used for the end product. So this system allows for keywords to emerge out of different conversations. We can search the conversations, listen to audio snippets, discover patterns, and so that's really what that system uses. And then what we want to accomplish today is really beginning a process of weaving almost like a virtual tapestry of conversations across the city. I have a lot to say. So this next part, we'll say verbatim. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to the MIT Center for Constructive Communication to retain the recording of this conversation in accordance with the mission of the Real Talk at Boston and transforming Boston into a listening city. You also understand that the conversation will be part of the Real Talk at Boston Public Conversation Collection with the goal to foster constructive communication across the city. The MIT Center for Constructive Communication will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that goal and with the mission to develop methods and tools that foster constructive communication in local communities. Participation in this conversation is voluntary and you can withdraw at any time without consequences. Sessions will be recorded, but you can opt out and have this recording deleted. Only the research team at the MIT CCC will have access to your data. Your identity will be protected and information won't be shared without permission unless required by law. There are minimal foreseen risks. However, with any conversation, there is a chance that you'll hear stories that elicit strong emotions. I'll support you in hosting a safe conversation where you only share what you feel comfortable sharing. And then I'm going to ask if everyone consents to this, if you can just come off with mute and say, I agree, and then we can move forward.

8.words: I'll go real quick. I came to Boston for school and, honestly, what initially attracted me to UMass Boston was the location. I immediately fell in love with that location. It was very peaceful and I loved how it was a ten-minute train, not a ten-minute train, like a ten-minute drive to downtown. So it was honestly, truly, the location, obviously the school, it just made sense for me.

17.words: Yeah, I'll piggyback off of Jas. I too feel like having worked... Originally I came from Oklahoma and I worked in Texas and California and so many different states. And one thing I recognize about Boston that is unique, or Massachusetts as a whole, is people are very understanding of circumstances. And so I felt like there was a level of flexibility that did not exist elsewhere. I also think that, again, like she said, transportation's pretty awesome here and I feel like that's a great support that people don't really think of. And I know there's a lot of work that goes into making it accessible.

18.words: I have kind of a funny one about what I felt like I belonged  in Boston. I was working a really terrible job, so not exactly the job that I came here for. And I was working during one of the big snowicannes  that we had seven years ago I think. And our office was right down the street from a Dunkin Donuts and I had to go and get Dunkin Donuts and there was a long line of people getting iced coffees immediately in front of me all getting the styrofoam on the outside of the plastic cup. But it was like everybody was out there because they were working. So there was just guys who drove plows and property managers like me and just like anybody who had to be out in the city that day was just in line and Dunkin Donuts talking to each other about how shitty it was that we all had to work in the snow and that we all had to come out and be out like this and it was the most quintessential Boston moment to me.

24.words: I would say for me, cost of living. I think rent is high here. That is just the truth. That's why we have a lot of people who are houseless. I'm tired of seeing people sleeping in bushes. I'm tired of seeing people sitting on corners and you know that they don't have anywhere else to go. And I'm tired of rent being so high. I think the opposite of what other people have said. I've lived in Oklahoma where transportation is non-existent so here it's like a dream. So I get that. But for me it's like Oklahoma has a decent cost of living. Here, it's so horrible. It's so so bad. So I think for me that is the biggest one because I think it trickles down into everything else.

25.words: I saw someone say that the Boston public transit is the most terrible thing ever unless you lived in a different city with worse public transit, which is most of them. I guess my job... Definitely housing because that's the biggest one I think. I was just waiting for that topic to come up. The cost of rent is insane. The fact that it's so difficult... It's difficult to impossible for anyone to build equity if you're not already starting out from position of privilege. And I think that as a city, I know that there already is a lot happening. I work in a job where I see a lot of things that are happening with housing shortages and what's going on in towns and cities in Massachusetts so I will say I'm glad that there is stuff happening and there's definitely a way better conversation about that than there used to be. But yeah, just the fact that there's this huge divide of any plan to own property, you're just paying rent and all of that money is not doing anything for you. It might kick up your credit by two points, but that's so ridiculous with the amount being spent on that.

35.words: Okay, I'll go. I would say that Boston, 10 years from now for me would be people would be able to live by themselves as one single person. They'll be able to have an apartment and be able to just, I don't know, live comfortably and not just paycheck to paycheck. I also think the streets will be cleaner and that it'll be more diverse instead of, there's Dorchester and Roxbury where it's majority of either Spanish or Black communities. And then you have Southie, that's like majority of white communities and I want that to be more of a mixture. So making that more accessible and also inclusive so people are able to afford to live in those places too. And then also education wise that our public school systems would be better and safer for our youth. So that's what I would like Boston to see being in 10 years.

36.words: To piggy off with Jas, I'll just add to it because I agree with everything she said. I would like to see more community organizations doing more things for neighborhoods so that we can have more of a community. I feel like people are really siloed away. There's not a lot of block parties, I feel like as there should be. There are not a lot of organizations for youth to go to, or if they are, they're super underfunded. So I would like to see community organizations have more funding so they can pay their people more so they can do more for the community. I just think that, as a whole, brings everybody up.

35.segment_words: I agree with everything she said.
35.linked_words: So that's what I would like Boston to see being in 10 years.

37.words: I think doesn't Cambridge have a block party grant program where if you say that you're planning a block party, they'll give you a $200 budget for snacks and things. I think they just started doing that recently, but I love that as a concept. I think, yeah exactly what's kind of already been said. I like living in East Boston because I feel like there are a lot of what I call public back yards. Just places where anybody in the community can go. There's parks, and there's playgrounds, and there's places to skate, and play basketball, whatever. And I think that having those places is so important. Also, because it's a mixing, a diverse mixing of everybody in the neighborhood rather than having super condos with all of those amenities already built into them, taking that land back and making it publicly accessible so that way there's actually good use out of them.
